content: I had added cover art. Restoring comment noting change.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Maybe other airlines will also adopt this method. I hate having to stand for minutes on narrow the aisle till all other passengers arrange their baggages in fron of me... :-)
Anyway, the puzzle statement was clear and test cases abundant. Puzzle is on the 'easy' side of 'medium', but current classification is fine for me.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear description and tests, i like the airplane boarding theme :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: lgtm

In the last validator (and only there), the output contain twice the same side, as you wrote in the example, "No one is getting on", the issue is that no test actually test such a case, you could easily end up with a "Now boarding: " without names.
Very nice puzzle !
Updated to remove the seat-number-as-part-of-name from the validators.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
This puzzle looks interesting. if you could provide one more example. It would be really easier to understand.
I like this puzzle! It is well solvable!

Input section
* {{n}} should be reformatted as [[n]] as it is a variable.

Cases
* w in the first pair of cases is odd. That violates the constraint that "w is even".
* The jump from the second pair of test/validator to the third pair is too large. I mean the number of passengers is small in the second pair, while the number is much bigger in the third pair. Honestly, I still don't understand the rules you wrote in the statement, and I would like to see a few more simple cases in between which illustrate the rules (e.g. unsold seats, the left/right/half notations, slightly larger group of passengers).

Thanks.

Thanks for the feedback - I've added a worked example to the statement, and changed the rules (ditched the alternating left/right per row) to be clearer, I hope.
I've also added a couple more mid-sized tests.
I've formatted the instances of names and seat numbers as constants; The guidelines aren't clear on whether only a variable's name should be formatted as a variable, or the variable's value as well.
Can do - is there a particular aspect of the problem that's not covered by the current example?
I'm not sure to be really clear here so if I am not please ask so that I can share my code, running it is self explainatory.
No, I get you - I'll adapt the test to better match the validator.
Done - "Half-full Wide-Body" is now the same seat numbers as the Validation, but with the names shuffled. Cheers for that, it was a good find.
Well I just had a typo so I had a "Now boarding: " without any name. Pure luck on that one.
i could see only one example in the IDE.
Most puzzles only give one example in the description.

yeah i understood that. if you look at the small flight validation after 2A, then second persong wil be 1A, which represent that line A will be boarded first then it goes to B. But if you look at the half full validation the boarding seat number is duplicated 2 times and 

Now boarding: 
Axl Rose 8A,Jonathan Archer 7A,Christopher Pike 6B,Bruce Lee 5B,Ziyi Zhang 4A,Graham Chapman 3A,Terry Gilliam 2C

Now boarding: Sonny Chiba 8E,Jackie Chan 7F,Michael Palin 6E,Terry Jones 5F,Dizzy Reed 4F,Duff McKagan 3D,Katherine Janeway 1F

Now boarding: Slash 8B,James Kirk 6C,Jet Li 4C,John Cleese 3B

Now boarding: Michelle Yeoh 7D,Eric Idle 6D,Matt Sorum 4E,Benjamin Sisko 1E

Now boarding: Izzy Stradling 8C

Now boarding: Jean-Luc Picard 1D

Here the last 3 rows results making more confused with the current statements. After passenger boarded into D again starting with C.

In the Half-Full validation test, I included the seat-numbers at the end of passengers' names mainly to make my own checking easier. Because it's only in a validation case, players will never see it, but I can remove, no problem.

I'm not clear about your issue with the "last 3 rows results":
Axl Rose etc: the first boarding on the left.
Sonny etc: the first boarding on the right.
Slash etc: the second boarding on the left.
Michelle etc: The second boarding on the right.
Izzy: the third boarding on the left (he has to wait until 8A and 8B have boarded)
Jean-Luc: the third boarding on the right (he has to wait until 1F and 1E have boarded)

All right, it looks much clearer now, thanks!

In my opinion, only the variable names should be formatted as variables.

A few things to touch up in Goal section:
* "from row 4 to row 1" are not formatted consistently in the example.
* There should be no spaces after the commas in the "Now boarding" lines, to be consistent with the required output format.

Thank you.
Done, and done.

Congrats on having your puzzle approved!

Would you consider uploading a cover picture for the puzzle?
Would you consider uploading a cover picture for the puzzle?
